Thursday was special at Elmhurst United Middle School and for OUSD's Nutrition Services team, as Rep. Barbara Lee stopped by to thank staff and volunteers for their service.

Wearing a mask emblazoned with the late Rep. John Lewis' words, "Good Trouble," she met with District leaders including Board of Education President Jody London, Director James Harris and Superintendent Kyla Johnson-Trammell.

The Congresswoman also handed out food to some families during the grab and go. She thanked the staff and volunteers and took photos with them, before speaking with assembled media. She told the media how critical the grab and go program has been for students and families in her district.

Rep. Lee said she will work to get the federal government to continue to allow all Oakland children 18 years old and younger, plus the District's Young Adult Program students, to receive food through the end of the school year.

Elmhurst and OUSD thank Rep. Lee for visiting, and for giving a boost to our families and staff during these challenging times. #iamOUSD

Farms to Communities was created in response to the pandemic and has helped provide 3,200 Oakland families at 40 schools with free, weekly home delivery of farm-fresh fruit and vegetables!

With their initial grant funding expired, they are transitioning to a more sustainable strategy. This is where you come in: If you place an order for a $35 bag delivered to your house, it will allow one of the Oakland families who were part of our program to receive a bag at a highly reduced price they can afford.

The weekly shopping bags have 12 - 15 pounds of organic and sustainably-grown produce, including basics like greens & potatoes as well as seasonal special items like peaches, strawberries, and melons. It's a win-win! Check it out: https://farmstocommunities.org/

We are now on the last day of our third week of school, and we hope that distance learning is treating everyone well. Remember that attendance is just as important now as it is when we are on our campuses. We don't want students missing out on any instruction.

Please remember these points:
- Attendance is taken every day for every period.
- We expect students to engage in every class every day and to communicate with us if they are facing challenges in distance learning.
- You will or have received an online attendance pledge that describes how families, students and schools can work together for success.

The good news is attendance has been excellent at most of our schools. In fact, there are schools that have achieved 98% or higher attendance through yesterday. They are Cleveland Elementary, Crocker Highlands, Hillcrest, International Community School, Melrose Leadership Academy, Oakland International High School, Peralta Elementary, and Thornhill. Way to go!

"My thoughts and concerns are always first and foremost with our students, families and staff. I think about how you are taking all of this in and coping, especially when compounded with the stress of facing COVID-19 over the past almost three months. I think about how these racist and unjust acts affect your own sense of self and development, and how so many of our parents, especially our African American parents, carry the burden of fear every time their sons and daughters walk out of their homes.

Of course, this is not abstract for me. My husband and I sat with our kids last night. With sirens in the background, we talked about oppression and injustice. We talked about not buying into the hate. We talked about being safe and what it means to be a young black person in this country. We talked while my heart was breaking for my kids, my husband, and myself, once again."

Join us today, May 22 at 4pm as we come together to celebrate the academic achievement of our Middle Eastern students!

“The number of high achieving students we are honoring has grown from 250 last year, to almost 300 this year with GPAs of 3.0 and above,” said Munera Mohsin, OUSD Middle School Regional Family Engagement Liaison. “Recognizing our culture and traditions gives our students a sense of pride, and motivates them to aim high and achieve their goals. This Second Annual celebration is historic. It is, of course, not how any of us imagined any graduation, promotion, or honor roll celebration would look. We wish we could celebrate together but the universe had other plans. Regardless, we are thrilled we can celebrate our students under any and all circumstances.”

To view the ceremony live or after it ends, please visit www.ousd.org/equity or the Office of Equity Youtube Page

Further details: https://t.e2ma.net/message/lj292c/xkz1ng

How should our schools come back from COVID-19?

There are so many choices ahead for our district about how to safely open schools and serve students and families. Oakland families like yours deserve a seat at the table as major decisions are being made about your child’s education.

That’s why OUSD has partnered with community organizations including GO Public Schools Oakland, NAACP, Bay Area PLAN, Latino Education Network, IKUNA, AAYSP, Banteay Srei, Asian Refugees United, and more, to launch the #SchoolAfterCOVID family survey.

Please share your experiences with distance learning and your thoughts on moving forward. The survey is available in multiple languages at https://www.ousd.org/covid-19survey

The survey is also available in paper format, and can be completed over the phone. To do the survey over the phone or to request a paper survey in English, Spanish, or Mam, families can call: (510) 473-2550‬

They created a whole new plan for how students would continue learning and thought about ways to keep students and families engaged in the school community. They attended webinars to learn new ways to connect, they flexed their technology muscles to utilize new software, they updated lesson plans, they personally reached out to families, and so much more.

Please take some time to appreciate our educators this coming week by sending an email, a card or posting on social media using the #ThankATeacher hashtag!

On Thursday, just after Garfield Elementary School wrapped up another great day of Grab and Go free meal service to our students and families, Superintendent Kyla Johnson-Trammell, Nutrition Services Executive Director Irene Reynolds, and Chief Systems and Services Officer Preston Thomas dropped in to thank the staff and volunteers who run such a successful program. This is day six of the Grab and Go Free Meal Program across the District. The Nutrition Services Team at 12 sites handed out meals for kids, and at Elmhurst United Middle School, in the first 15 minutes, they served meals to 245 students and families. That's close to 1500 meals.

At CCPA, there was a steady stream of families coming in to pick up meals. Volunteers there also were handing out information about the 2020 Census.

At each site, the Alameda County Community Food Bank handed out bags of groceries. And the World Central Kitchen gave out meals for adults. The Golden State Warriors donated thousands of tote bags so people could carry their food away. SupplyBank.Org and Stephen and Ayesha Curry's organization, Eat Learn Play Foundation are big supporters of this effort. And officers from the Oakland Police Department also handed out meals and even delivered them to families at their homes.

OUSD thanks all these wonderful partner organizations, the volunteers and our staff for supporting our students and their families. #iamOUSD

OUSD is asking all families to do the 2020 Census to let the federal government know how many people we have in our District, our city and our region so that we receive the proper amount of resources and representation in Congress. It's important to know that you will not be asked any questions about immigration status. You can do it by filling out the form you received and mailing it back, calling in to do it by phone, and doing it online.

This poster was one of the winners of OUSD's 2020 Census Poster contest, created by Lily A., a 6th grader at Montera. Great work, Lily! #2020Census #iamOUSD
